Homarus gammarus , known as the European lobster or common lobster , is a species of clawed lobster from the eastern Atlantic Ocean , Mediterranean Sea and parts of the Black Sea . It is closely related to the American lobster , H. americanus . It may grow to a length of 60 cm ( 24 in ) and a mass of 6 kilograms ( 13 lb ) , and bears a conspicuous pair of claws . In life , the lobsters are blue , only becoming " lobster red " on cooking . Mating occurs in the summer , producing eggs which are carried by the females for up to a year before hatching into planktonic larvae . Homarus gammarus is a highly esteemed food , and is widely caught using lobster pots , mostly around the British Isles . 
 Homarus gammarus is a large crustacean , with a body length up to 60 centimetres ( 24 in ) and weighing up to 5 – 6 kilograms ( 11 – 13 lb ) , although the lobsters caught in lobster pots are usually 23 – 38 cm ( 9 – 15 in ) long and weigh 0 @.@ 7 – 2 @.@ 2 kg ( 1 @.@ 5 – 4 @.@ 9 lb ) . This may occur several times a year for young lobsters , but decreases to once every 1 – 2 years for larger animals . 
 The first pair of pereiopods is armed with a large , asymmetrical pair of claws . The larger one is the " crusher " , and has rounded nodules used for crushing prey ; the other is the " cutter " , which has sharp inner edges , and is used for holding or tearing the prey . Usually , the left claw is the crusher , and the right is the cutter . 
 The exoskeleton is generally blue above , with spots that coalesce , and yellow below . The red colour associated with lobsters only appears after cooking . This occurs because , in life , the red pigment astaxanthin is bound to a protein complex , but the complex is broken up by the heat of cooking , releasing the red pigment .

The female carries the eggs for up to 12 months , depending on the temperature , attached to her pleopods . Females carrying eggs are said to be " berried " and can be found throughout the year . 
 The eggs hatch at night , and the larvae swim to the water surface where they drift with the ocean currents , preying on zooplankton . This stage involves three moults and lasts for 15 – 35 days . After the third moult , the juvenile takes on a form closer to the adult , and adopts a benthic lifestyle .  Air Vice Marshal Frank Headlam , CB , CBE ( 15 July 1914 – 23 December 1976 ) was a senior commander in the Royal Australian Air Force ( RAAF ) . Born and educated in Tasmania , he joined the RAAF as an air cadet in January 1934 . He specialised in flying instruction and navigation before the outbreak of World War II . In April 1941 , he became commanding officer of No. 2 Squadron , which operated Lockheed Hudsons . The squadron was deployed to Dutch Timor in December , and saw action against Japanese forces in the South West Pacific . After returning to Australia in February 1942 , Headlam held staff appointments and training commands , finishing the war a group captain .

His tenure as DCAS coincided with the most significant rearmament program the Air Force had undertaken since World War II , and with manpower shortages stemming from this expansion and from Australia 's increasing involvement in the security of South East Asia . rewritten: Homarus gammarus, commonly referred to as the European lobster, is a type of clawed lobster found in the eastern Atlantic Ocean, Mediterranean Sea, and certain areas of the Black Sea. This species, closely related to the American lobster (H. americanus), can reach sizes of up to 60 cm (24 in) in length and weigh as much as 6 kilograms (13 lb), featuring a distinctive pair of claws. While alive, these lobsters display a blue hue, turning to the classic "lobster red" color when cooked. Breeding typically takes place during the summer months, with females carrying eggs for nearly a year until they hatch into planktonic larvae. Highly prized as a culinary delicacy, Homarus gammarus is predominantly harvested using lobster pots, particularly in the vicinity of the British Isles.

Homarus gammarus is a sizable crustacean, reaching a body length of up to 60 centimetres (24 in) and a weight of 5-6 kilograms (11-13 lb). However, lobsters typically caught in traps are around 23-38 cm (9-15 in) long and weigh between 0.7-2.2 kg (1.5-4.9 lb). Similar to other crustaceans, lobsters possess a tough exoskeleton that they must shed to facilitate growth, a process known as ecdysis or moulting. While young lobsters may undergo this process multiple times a year, larger specimens typically moult once every 1-2 years.

The initial set of pereiopods features a significant, unevenly sized pair of claws. One claw, known as the "crusher," is larger and equipped with rounded nodules designed for crushing prey, while the other, called the "cutter," has sharp inner edges for gripping or tearing the prey. Typically, the crusher is situated on the left side, with the cutter on the right.

The exoskeleton is typically blue on top, merging into spots, and yellow underneath. The red hue seen in cooked lobsters is due to the breakdown of the protein complex that binds the red astaxanthin pigment when exposed to heat, releasing the red pigment.

The American lobster, Homarus americanus, is the most closely related species to H. gammarus. Despite their strong resemblance and the possibility of artificial hybridization, natural interbreeding in the wild is rare due to their non-overlapping habitats. Several distinguishing features differentiate these two species.

Female H. gammarus become sexually mature when their carapace length reaches 80 to 85 millimeters (3.1 to 3.3 inches), while males mature at a slightly smaller size. Mating usually takes place in the summer between a female that has recently molted, making her shell soft, and a male with a hard shell. The female carries the eggs attached to her pleopods for about 12 months, with the duration influenced by the temperature. Females carrying eggs, known as "berried," can be observed at any time of the year.

The eggs typically hatch during the night, and the larvae then migrate to the water surface, where they passively drift with the ocean currents, feeding on zooplankton. This larval stage consists of three molts and spans a period of 15 to 35 days. Following the third molt, the young creatures assume a more adult-like form and transition to a benthic existence. Although sightings of these juveniles are rare in their natural habitat, they are known to possess the ability to excavate extensive burrows. It is estimated that only about 1 larva in every 20,000 successfully reaches the benthic phase. Upon reaching a carapace length of 15 mm (0.59 in), the juveniles emerge from their burrows and embark on their adult lives.

Homarus gammarus is distributed throughout the northeastern Atlantic Ocean, ranging from northern Norway to the Azores and Morocco, excluding the Baltic Sea. It can be found in most parts of the Mediterranean Sea, with the exception of the region east of Crete, and along the northwestern coast of the Black Sea. The species is also present in the Norwegian fjords and in the Arctic Circle, with the northernmost populations residing there.

The species can be categorized into four genetically separate populations: one that is widespread, and three that have evolved separately likely because of small effective population sizes, potentially in response to local environmental conditions. The initial group includes lobsters from northern Norway, known as the "midnight-sun lobster." The populations in the Mediterranean Sea differ from those in the Atlantic Ocean. The final unique population is located in the Netherlands: specimens from the area were distinguishable from those gathered in the North Sea or English Channel.

Efforts have been undertaken to introduce H. gammarus to New Zealand, along with other European species like the edible crab, Cancer pagurus. From 1904 to 1914, a million lobster larvae were released from hatcheries in Dunedin, but the species failed to establish itself in the region.

Fully grown H. gammarus are typically found on the continental shelf, usually inhabiting depths ranging from 0 to 150 meters, with a tendency not to venture beyond 50 meters. They exhibit a preference for solid surfaces like rocks or compact mud, residing within crevices or burrows and emerging during the night for feeding activities.

The disease <unk>, which is caused by the bacterium <unk> <unk>, is known to affect Homarus gammarus. While it is commonly found in American lobsters, cases of the disease have only been observed in captive H. gammarus, with the possibility of previous occupation of the tanks by H. americanus.

Homarus gammarus, known as the European lobster, has long been held in high regard as a culinary delicacy and even found its way into a seventeenth-century English folk song. This species commands premium prices and is available fresh, frozen, canned, or as a powder. The white meat, described as excellent, can be found in both the claws and abdomen, while most of the cephalothorax is also edible. The only inedible parts are the gastric mill and the gut, also known as the "sand vein." Notably, the European lobster can cost up to three times more than its American counterpart, Homarus americanus, due to its superior flavor profile.

Lobsters are primarily caught using lobster pots, although occasionally they can be lured out by lines baited with octopus or cuttlefish to facilitate capture with a net or by hand. In 2008, a total of 4,386 tonnes of H. gammarus were harvested in Europe and North Africa, with the British Isles (including the Channel Islands) accounting for 3,462 tonnes (79%). The required minimum landing size for H. gammarus is a carapace length of 87 mm (3.4 inches).

H. gammarus has been designated as the type species of the genus Homarus Weber, 1795, following Direction 51 by the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature. Confusion had previously arisen due to the species being known by various names, such as Astacus marinus Fabricius, 1775, and Homarus vulgaris H. Milne-Edwards, 1837. Additionally, Friedrich Weber's genus description was overlooked until its rediscovery by Mary Rathbun, thereby invalidating any previous assignments of type species (Homarus H. Milne-Edwards, 1837) for Homarus Weber, 1795.

In 1974, <unk> Holthuis designated a lectotype for Homarus gammarus, which originated from 57°53′N 11°32′E, close to Marstrand, Sweden (approximately 48 kilometers or 30 miles northwest of Gothenburg). Unfortunately, both the lectotype and the original specimen have been misplaced.

Air Vice Marshal Frank Headlam, CB, CBE (15 July 1914 – 23 December 1976), was a high-ranking officer in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). He was born and raised in Tasmania and enlisted in the RAAF as an air cadet in January 1934. Prior to the start of World War II, he focused on flight instruction and navigation. In April 1941, he assumed command of No. 2 Squadron, which was equipped with Lockheed Hudsons. The squadron was sent to Dutch Timor in December and engaged in combat against Japanese forces in the South West Pacific. Upon their return to Australia in February 1942, Headlam took on various administrative roles and training positions, ultimately concluding the war as a group captain.

Headlam held various key military positions throughout his career. He was the Officer Commanding North-Western Area in 1946, Director of Training from 1947 to 1950, and during the Malayan Emergency in 1950-51, he commanded No. 90 (Composite) Wing and RAF Tengah in Singapore. He also acted as Air Member for Personnel twice, in 1957 and 1959-60, and was honored as a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 1958. Subsequently promoted to air vice marshal, he served in roles such as Air Officer Commanding Operational Command in 1961-62, AOC No. 224 Group RAF from 1962 to 1965 during the Indonesia-Malaysia Konfrontasi, Deputy Chief of the Air Staff in 1965-66, and AOC Support Command in 1966-67. In recognition of his contributions, he was appointed a Companion of the Order of the Bath in 1965. After completing his role as Head of the Australian Joint Services Staff in London from 1968 to 1971, he retired from the Air Force and passed away in Melbourne five years later.

Frank Headlam, the son of Malcolm and Hilda Headlam, was born on 15 July 1914 in Launceston, Tasmania. He received his education at <unk> College in Hobart and graduated in 1932. Despite his parents' objections, he enlisted in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) as an air cadet on 16 January 1934. He received flight training at No. 1 Flying Training School (FTS) located at RAAF Point Cook, Victoria, and was appointed as a pilot officer on 1 January 1935.

Upon completing a conversion course, Headlam was designated to the Seaplane Squadron located at Point Cook. Described as no more than a flight in the official history of the pre-war RAAF, the Seaplane Squadron was a component of No. 1 FTS and utilized various aircraft such as Supermarine Southampton flying boats and de Havilland Gipsy Moth floatplanes. It was during this assignment that Headlam was elevated to the rank of flying officer on 1 July 1935. Noteworthy is the paper he authored on national defense during this time, proposing that Australia could achieve near invulnerability by bolstering its air forces, naval forces (including submarines), and fixed defenses. As noted by Air Force historian Alan Stephens, this paper essentially laid the groundwork for the enduring 'anti-lodgment' concept in RAAF strategic planning.

In July 1936, Headlam successfully completed a flying instructors course and became a part of the staff at No. 1 FTS. His promotion to flight lieutenant took place on 1 March 1937. Starting in July 1938, he participated in the RAAF's inaugural Long Specialist Navigation Course held at Point Cook, led by Flight Lieutenants Bill Garing and Alister Murdoch. The course included a series of challenging training flights that garnered significant media coverage, such as a noteworthy twelve-day, 10,800-kilometer round-Australia journey involving three Avro Ansons, with Headlam piloting one of them in November. The subsequent month, he guided the Ansons on a six-day expedition across Central Australia. Headlam excelled in the navigation course, earning a special distinction upon completion. On 27 January 1939, he assumed the role of a flight commander at RAAF Station Laverton, Victoria. Initially assigned to No. 2 Squadron, he later moved to No. 1 Squadron on 29 August, both of which operated Ansons.

After the start of World War II, No. 1 Squadron was involved in escorting convoys and conducting maritime reconnaissance missions off the southeastern coast of Australia. Headlam remained with the squadron as a flight commander until January 15, 1940, when he was reassigned to Headquarters Laverton as the navigation officer. By March 27, he was transferred to the RAAF Headquarters in Melbourne. His rank was elevated to squadron leader on June 1, 1940. Shortly after, he wed Katherine Bridge at St Paul's Anglican Church in Frankston. They later had a son and a daughter.

Headlam took over the command of No. 2 Squadron at Laverton on 15th April 1941 and was promoted to wing commander on 1st July the same year. The squadron, equipped with Lockheed Hudsons, primarily conducted maritime patrols in the southern waters until 5th December. At that point, following concerns of Japanese aggression in the Pacific, four aircraft from the squadron were dispatched to Darwin, Northern Territory. On 7th December, this group set up base at Penfui near Koepang in Dutch Timor, while the remaining eight Hudsons of No. 2 Squadron were put on standby in Darwin. The next day, upon the declaration of war in the Pacific, one of the Penfui-based Hudsons took action against the suspected radio ship Nanyo Maru, forcing it to run aground. By 12th December, Headlam had moved to Penfui, assuming command of both the base and No. 2 Squadron.

In January 1942, No. 2 Squadron had its aircraft dispersed across Penfui, <unk> Island, and Darwin. The Penfui detachment engaged in combat with Japanese forces involved in the Celebes invasion. During an attack on a transport ship on 11 January, two Hudsons successfully took down or damaged three Japanese floatplanes, but were later shot down by Mitsubishi Zeros on the following day. Penfui was first bombed by the Japanese on 26 January 1942 and continued to be a target, resulting in damage to some aircraft. While the intact Hudsons were relocated to Darwin, Headlam and his team remained at Penfui to assist in reconnaissance missions from Australia. Eventually, on 18 February, Headlam received orders to evacuate all personnel except for a small group tasked with demolishing the airfield with Sparrow Force's support. He returned to Darwin the next day, coinciding with the city's initial Japanese air raid. Subsequently, four of No. 2 Squadron's Hudsons were lost in the attack, prompting the relocation of the remaining aircraft to Daly Waters for further reconnaissance and bombing missions against Japanese targets in Timor.

Headlam continued his service in Darwin as the Controller of Operations at Headquarters North @-@ Western Area Command until May 12, 1942. He then moved to Nhill, Victoria, to lead No. 2 Air Navigation School, where Ansons were in operation. In June, No. 97 (Reserve) Squadron was established using personnel from the school. Subsequently, on July 20, 1943, Headlam assumed command of No. 2 Air Observer School at Mount Gambier, South Australia, also utilizing Ansons. His promotion to group captain occurred on December 1, 1943, followed by his appointment as the first commanding officer of No. 3 Squadron, operating Ansons and Fairey Battles from Port Pirie, on December 9. After relinquishing command of No. 3 Squadron, he enrolled in RAAF Staff School in Mount Martha, Victoria, on October 2, 1944. Later, on January 12, 1945, he was designated as the senior administrative staff officer at North @-@ Western Area Command.

Headlam took on the role of Officer Commanding North-Western Area in January 1946. Towards the end of that year, he was stationed in Britain where he attended the Royal Air Force Staff College in Andover and worked at RAAF Overseas Headquarters in London. Upon his return to Australia in November 1947, he assumed the position of Director of Training at RAAF Headquarters. In November 1950, he was tasked with leading No. 90 (Composite) Wing, succeeding Group Captain Paddy Heffernan. Based at RAF Changi in Singapore, No. 90 Wing oversaw RAAF units involved in operations during the Malayan Emergency: No. 1 (Bomber) Squadron, which flew Avro Lincolns, and No. 38 (Transport) Squadron, operating Douglas C-47 Dakotas. The Avro Lincolns carried out bombing missions over communist-held areas and targeted specific locations. The Douglas Dakotas were responsible for courier services, VIP transportation, medical evacuations across Southeast Asia, troop and cargo airlifts in Malaya, supply drops to friendly forces, and dissemination of propaganda leaflets. Headlam sustained minor injuries on December 20 when a Dakota from No. 38 Squadron, which he was co-piloting, crash-landed at Kampong Aur in Pahang due to engine failure. In August 1951, he was appointed as the commander of RAF Tengah in Singapore while still holding the position of commanding officer of No. 90 Wing. Headlam relinquished command of No. 90 Wing in December 1951.

On 19th February 1952, Headlam assumed the role of senior air staff officer (SASO) at Eastern Area Command in Penrith, New South Wales. During his tenure as SASO, the RAAF initiated the adoption of English Electric Canberra jet bombers and CAC Sabre jet fighters. The Air Force underwent a significant restructuring, shifting from a location-based command-and-control system to a functional one, leading to the establishment of Home (operational), Training, and Maintenance Commands. Recognized as a de facto operational headquarters due to its control over numerous combat units, Eastern Area Command was restructured as Home Command in October 1953. In recognition of his outstanding skills and dedication, Headlam was honored as an Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) in the 1954 New Year Honours. He was subsequently promoted to acting air commodore in May and appointed as aide-de-camp to Queen Elizabeth II on 7th October 1954.

On 1 January 1955, Headlam was elevated to the rank of substantive air commodore. Subsequently, he was assigned to RAAF Overseas Headquarters in London in November and attended courses at the Imperial Defence College the following year. Upon his return to Australia, he assumed the role of acting Air Member for Personnel at the Department of Air in Canberra, serving between 19 March and 21 October 1957, and then again from 24 August 1959 to 28 March 1960. During these periods, Headlam held a position on the Air Board, the governing body of the service chaired by the Chief of the Air Staff. He also represented the RAAF on a committee, led by William John Allison, which evaluated defense service conditions, resulting in enhanced benefits such as a doubled flight pay. Headlam's responsibilities at the Department of Air included serving as Air Commodore Plans from October 1957 to January 1959, and as Director General Plans and Policy from January to August 1959, overseeing the RAAF's Directorate of Intelligence. In recognition of his contributions, Headlam was honored as a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 1958 Queen's Birthday Honours, announced on 3 June. His career progression continued as he assumed the role of acting Deputy Chief of the Air Staff in May 1960.

On 30 January 1961, Headlam began working at Operational Command (OPCOM), which had replaced Home Command and oversaw the direction of RAAF operational units. In April, he assumed the role of Air Officer Commanding (AOC) OPCOM, succeeding Air Vice Marshal Val Hancock. He was promoted to air vice marshal on 29 May. Headlam was then assigned to RAAF Base Butterworth, Malaya on 17 July 1962, where he took on the position of AOC No. 224 Group RAF in Singapore a week later. Air Vice Marshal Alister Murdoch took over as AOC OPCOM. While serving as AOC No. 224 Group, Headlam was responsible for regional air defense and offensive air operations during the Brunei Rebellion in December 1962, and the subsequent Konfrontasi between Indonesia and Malaysia the following month. After divorcing his first wife in 1956, he married widowed social worker Vernon Spence at the Sydney registry office on 20 January 1964. He handed over No. 224 Group to Air Vice Marshal Christopher Foxley-Norris on 30 November.

Upon his return to Australia, Headlam assumed the position of Deputy Chief of the Air Staff (DCAS) on 26 January 1965. He was honored as a Companion of the Order of the Bath (CB) on 22 June for his exceptional service in the Borneo Territories. During his tenure as DCAS, the Air Force engaged in its most significant rearmament effort since World War II. The Air Force faced challenges due to manpower shortages resulting from its expanded operations in Southeast Asia. Towards the end of his term, the first RAAF helicopters were deployed to the Vietnam War. Headlam, alongside Lieutenant General Sir John Wilton, traveled to Saigon in March 1966 to strategize the deployment. His subsequent role as AOC Support Command in Melbourne, succeeding Air Vice Marshal Douglas Candy on 8 August 1966, involved overseeing the amalgamation of the RAAF’s former Training and Maintenance Commands. In January 1968, Headlam assumed the position of Head of the Australian Joint Services Staff in London. Additionally, he served as an Extra Gentleman Usher to the Queen from 17 November 1970 to 5 June 1971.

Headlam returned to Australia in June 1971 and then proceeded to take resettlement leave. Subsequently, he retired from the Air Force on 3 August. Settling in Melbourne, he passed away at the age of 62 on 23 December 1976 after bravely fighting cancer for an extended period. He is survived by his children and his second wife. A private funeral was held in his honor, and he was cremated at Springvale Crematorium.

M-82 is a state highway located in Michigan's Lower Peninsula, connecting Fremont and Howard City. Passing through Fremont and along the southern boundary of Manistee National Forest, the route has a history dating back to the 1920s. Originally established in the Upper Peninsula in 1919, M-82 has undergone alterations over the years, with terminus changes as far west as New Era or Hesperia. The current alignment was settled in the late 1970s.

M-82 commences at an intersection with M-120 and B-96, located west of Fremont, where the county lines converge. M-120 delineates the north-south boundaries of Newaygo-Oceana and Newaygo-Muskegon counties. On the other hand, B-96, which marks the east-west division of Oceana-Muskegon counties, stretches directly west from this crossroads. To the east of the intersection, M-82 follows 48th Street, passing through agricultural landscapes before reaching Fremont. Upon entering the town, the road transforms into Main Street, traversing the downtown area until M-82 veers south onto Stewart Avenue. Continuing eastward on 72nd Street, the highway meanders through more farmland until it nears Newaygo, where the surroundings become increasingly wooded near the Muskegon River. Upon reaching Newaygo, M-82 follows Fremont Street to meet M-37, merging briefly to cross the river into downtown via State Street. South of the city center, M-82 turns eastward, diverging from M-37, and proceeds along 82nd Street, bordering the southern edge of the Manistee National Forest. Finally, the eastern terminus of M-82 is located at exit 118 on US 131/M-46, situated west of Howard City.

As part of its maintenance duties, the Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) monitors traffic levels on its roadways using a metric known as average annual daily traffic (AADT), which calculates the daily traffic average on a road segment throughout the year. In 2009, MDOT's data revealed that a section of M-82, located west of Fremont, recorded the highest traffic volume on the highway at 16,532 vehicles per day, while the lowest traffic volume was observed at 4,018 vehicles east of Newaygo. Furthermore, none of MDOT's highway sections have been included in the National Highway System, a network of roads crucial for the nation's economy, defense, and transportation.

The present-day M-82, established in 1926, originally connected US 31 in Hart to the northern intersection of US 131 and M-46 in Howard City, passing through Ferry, Hesperia, and Fremont, replacing the former M-41 route. In the late 1930s, M-46 was prolonged to include the segment between Newaygo and Howard City, resulting in a shared M-46/M-82 route to bridge a gap in the M-46 pathway. By 1938, this shared stretch became solely designated as M-46, resulting in M-82 being truncated back to the northern junction of M-37 in Newaygo. In the late 1940s, or early 1948, the highway was relocated to a new course west of Ferry, extending westward to its new terminus in Shelby instead of its initial direction towards Hart.

In 1963 and 1964, there were two realignments that altered the western section of the highway once again, redirecting it from Hesperia to New Era, bypassing Ferry. A significant change occurred around 1969 when highway designations in Oceana County were revamped. M-20 took over the section west of Hesperia previously designated as M-82, now terminating at New Era instead of Muskegon. M-120 was introduced to replace M-20 south of Hesperia. Consequently, M-82's route was shortened to only run from Hesperia to Newaygo. The highway's length was extended in 1973 by relocating its eastern end back to Howard City. M-46 was rerouted to run along the US 131 freeway south of Howard City to Cedar Springs, replacing M-57 between Cedar Springs and Casnovia. This adjustment allowed the highway between Newaygo and Howard City to revert to the M-82 designation. The final modification occurred in 1978 when the overlap with M-120 was removed in favor of M-120 solely. At that time, the M-82 designation was cut back to the junction west of Fremont, establishing the current highway configuration.

Shikamaru Nara, also known as Nara Shikamaru, is a character from the Naruto manga and anime series by Masashi Kishimoto. In the series, Shikamaru is a ninja from the village of Konohagakure and a member of Team 10 along with Choji Akimichi, Ino Yamanaka, and their leader Asuma Sarutobi. Despite his exceptional intelligence, Shikamaru is depicted as lazy and often avoids using his abilities. Kishimoto appreciates Shikamaru's laid-back personality. Apart from the original series, Shikamaru has made appearances in four Naruto films and various other related media such as video games and original animations.

Shikamaru's character has been extensively discussed in various anime and manga sources. Reviewers often highlight his lazy disposition and sharp intellect, observing his development into a capable leader. Anime News Network particularly praised his unexpected evolution into a hero within the Naruto series. Shikamaru enjoys significant popularity among Naruto readers, consistently ranking well in popularity surveys. A range of Shikamaru-themed merchandise, such as action figures, keychains, and patches, has been made available to fans.

Masashi Kishimoto has expressed his fondness for Shikamaru, appreciating his relaxed demeanor alongside his exceptional intelligence. He contrasted Shikamaru with Sasuke Uchiha, who possesses intellect but displays a more abrasive personality. Kishimoto humorously mentioned that if he were a girl, he would marry Shikamaru, acknowledging Shikamaru's potential for success in life. In creating Shikamaru's appearance in Part II, Kishimoto aimed to give him a distinctive look despite outfitting him with a common ninja vest seen in the series. To maintain this uniqueness, he placed Shikamaru's forehead protector on his arm to keep his hair visible.

Shikamaru makes his first significant appearance in the series during the Chunin Exams, which are bi-annual tests for ninjas aiming to progress in rank. He belongs to Team 10 with Choji Akimichi and Ino Yamanaka. Despite his strong aversion to putting in effort, Shikamaru is remarkably intelligent; his mentor, Asuma Sarutobi, estimated his IQ to be over 200. His skills revolve around the Shadow Imitation Technique, the trademark ability of his clan. This technique allows him to merge his shadow with an opponent's, rendering them immobile and compelled to mirror Shikamaru's actions. As the storyline advances, Shikamaru refines his shadow manipulation techniques. In the later part of the series, he demonstrates the capacity to execute multiple shadow-based tactics simultaneously and raise his shadow from the ground to interact with physical objects. For instance, he can impale foes with shadow tendrils or employ them to hurl weapons.

Approaching the exams with a lack of enthusiasm, Shikamaru faces Temari from Sunagakure in a battle where he emerges victorious but opts to concede the match due to depleted chakra levels. Despite this setback, he stands out among his peers and gets promoted to Chunin, as the exam proctors were impressed by his strategic prowess exhibited during the fight with Temari. Assigned as the leader of a team, Shikamaru's mission is to stop Sasuke Uchiha from joining Otogakure village. While his team successfully defeats the Otogakure ninjas obstructing their path, Sasuke still manages to evade capture.

In the second part of the series, Shikamaru is given the mission to locate two individuals affiliated with the criminal group Akatsuki. Despite the successful identification of their targets by his team, one of the Akatsuki's immortal members fatally wounds Asuma Sarutobi during the confrontation, despite Shikamaru's valiant efforts. After bidding farewell to Asuma at his funeral, Shikamaru embarks on a quest for vengeance alongside the surviving members of Team 10, aided by Kakashi Hatake. While the rest of the team confronts Akatsuki's associate, Shikamaru ensures justice for Asuma by defeating the immortal member and ensuring their body remains unrecoverable. Following this intense battle, Shikamaru pledges to safeguard Kurenai and Asuma's infant daughter. He later joins the Fourth Division with Temari and others, serving as a deputy general under Gaara. In the series' conclusion, after revealing his personal aspirations during the final battles, Shikamaru marries Temari and becomes the advisor to the Seventh Hokage, Naruto, and welcomes a son named <unk> Nara into their family.

Apart from appearing in the Naruto anime and manga, Shikamaru is featured in seven films in the series. In the second film, he assists Naruto Uzumaki and Sakura Haruno in battling Haido, an idealist aiming to dominate the world using a mysterious power. In the fourth film, Shikamaru is briefly shown fighting a group of stone soldiers. In the fifth film, he joins Kakashi and Sai on a mission to locate the Land of Sky's base planning to attack Konoha. The sixth film depicts Shikamaru, Sakura, and Sai fighting a chimera beast summoned by Hiruko. In the eighth film, he fights against the demon Satori. The ninth film showcases a plump version of Shikamaru in the Limited Tsukuyomi universe, contrasting with his usual teammate, who becomes the team strategist. In the tenth film, Shikamaru leads a team sent to rescue Hinata's sister, Hanabi, abducted by Otsutsuki. Additionally, he features in the third original video animation, participating in a tournament. Shikamaru is a playable character in various Naruto video games, including the Clash of Ninja and Ultimate Ninja series, showcasing unique variations of his Shadow Imitation Technique. Notably, his Part II appearance is first seen in Naruto Shippūden: Gekitō Ninja Taisen! EX 2 video game.

The light novel "Shikamaru Hiden: A Cloud Drifting in Silent Darkness," authored by Takashi Yano and illustrated by Kishimoto, revolves around Shikamaru as both the protagonist and narrator. Taking place two years post the Fourth Ninja War, the story delves into Shikamaru's role as the coordinator of the newly established Shinobi Union tasked with apprehending a renegade ninja governing the faraway Land of Silence. This rogue ninja aims to institute a novel social order led by the ordinary populace. The narrative also delves into Shikamaru's evolving bond with Temari, leading up to the poignant struggle he faces in choosing a name for their child in the years following the novel's conclusion.

Shikamaru has consistently achieved high rankings in the Weekly Shōnen Jump popularity polls for the series, consistently securing a position in the top ten and even reaching fourth place in a particular poll. The most recent poll conducted in 2011 saw Shikamaru placed ninth, trailing behind Sasori and leading ahead of Hinata. Various merchandise featuring Shikamaru has been launched, such as action figures, key chains, and patches showcasing both his appearances in Part I and Part II. Among NTT customers, Shikamaru was voted as the sixteenth most favored black-haired male anime character. CyberConnect2 CEO Hiroshi Matsuyama expressed Shikamaru as one of his preferred characters from the Naruto series.

Multiple sources covering manga, anime, video games, and related media have provided insights on Shikamaru's character. According to IGN, Shikamaru stands out as a favorite character characterized by his lack of enthusiasm and untapped potential, labeling him as a representative figure for Generation X. In a specific episode review (110), IGN commended Shikamaru's transformation from a lazy individual to a capable leader when tasked with leading a team to retrieve Sasuke Uchiha, endorsing his promotion to Chunin. Anime News Network also highlighted Shikamaru's unexpected evolution into a hero as a standout moment in the storyline. Reflecting on episode 135 where Shikamaru's team fails to retrieve Sasuke and suffers injuries, IGN praised the poignant scene where Shikamaru expresses emotion upon learning his friends will recover, acknowledging his growth as a leader. Justin Rich of Mania Entertainment lauded Shikamaru's exceptional intelligence, hailing him as one of the series' most intriguing and skilled fighters in shōnen anime. Meridian, located in Mississippi, is the state's sixth-largest city. It serves as the county seat of Lauderdale County and is the primary city in the Meridian, Mississippi Micropolitan Statistical Area. Positioned along key highways, Meridian is situated 93 miles (150 km) east of Jackson, Mississippi; 154 miles (248 km) west of Birmingham, Alabama; 202 miles (325 km) northeast of New Orleans, Louisiana; and 231 miles (372 km) southeast of Memphis, Tennessee.

Founded in 1860 at the junction of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad and Southern Railway of Mississippi, Meridian thrived as a pivotal trading hub reliant on the railways for transportation of goods. However, during the Battle of Meridian in February 1864, General William Tecumseh Sherman destroyed a significant portion of the city during the American Civil War.

After the war, the city underwent significant reconstruction, leading to a period of prosperity known as its "Golden Age." Between 1890 and 1930, it emerged as the largest city in Mississippi and a prominent industrial hub in the Southern region, boasting a daily influx and outflux of 44 trains. The construction of Union Station in 1906 transformed it into a modern multi-modal transportation center, facilitating access to the Meridian Transit System, Greyhound Buses, and Trailways, accommodating an average of 242,360 passengers annually. While the city's economy initially suffered from the railroad sector's decline, it has since diversified, with healthcare, military, and manufacturing emerging as the primary employers by 2010. As per 2008 census data, the city's population within its boundaries is estimated at 38,232. However, the city's economy is also supported by a larger population of 232,900 within a 45-mile radius and 526,500 within a 65-mile radius, with 104,600 and 234,200 individuals in the respective labor forces.

The region is supported by two military bases, Naval Air Station Meridian and Key Field, generating employment for over 4,000 individuals. NAS Meridian houses the Regional Counter-Drug Training Academy (RCTA) and the inaugural Department of Homeland Security at the local level in the state. Key Field, named after Fred and Al Key, who achieved a global endurance flight record in 1935, currently accommodates the 186th Air Refueling Wing of the Air National Guard and serves as a base for the 185th Aviation Brigade of the Army National Guard. Rush Foundation Hospital stands as the primary non-military employer in the area, with a workforce of 2,610.

Meridian boasts a variety of arts institutions and historic edifices such as the Riley Center, the Meridian Museum of Art, Meridian Little Theatre, and the Meridian Symphony Orchestra. The city once housed two Carnegie libraries, distinct for white and African American patrons. The Carnegie Branch Library, which no longer stands, was part of a series of Carnegie libraries constructed for Black communities in the South during the period of segregation.

Meridian, known as the birthplace of Jimmie Rodgers, the "Father of Country Music," has been chosen as the future site of the Mississippi Arts and Entertainment Center. The city's Highland Park features a museum exhibiting memorabilia from Rodgers' life, as well as historic railroad equipment from the steam-engine era. Additionally, Highland Park is home to the Highland Park Dentzel Carousel, recognized as a National Historic Landmark and the only two-row stationary Dentzel menagerie carousel in the world. Notable Meridian natives include Miss America 1986 Susan Akin, civil rights activist James Chaney, who tragically lost his life in the 1964 Mississippi civil rights workers murders, and Hartley Peavey, the founder of Peavey Electronics headquartered in Meridian. The federal courthouse in the city was the venue for the 1966-1967 trial of the suspects involved in the murder of Chaney and two other activists, marking the first instance where a white jury convicted a white official of a civil rights crime.

Once home to the Choctaw Native Americans, the region known today as Meridian was acquired by the United States in 1830 through the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek as part of the Indian Removal era. Following the treaty's approval, European American pioneers started to settle in the area.

Upon being granted approximately 2,000 acres (810 ha) of federal land, Richard McLemore, the original settler of Meridian, initiated the practice of granting free land to newcomers with the aim of attracting more residents to the area and fostering its growth. The bulk of McLemore's land was acquired in 1853 by Lewis A. Ragsdale, an attorney from Alabama, while the remaining 80 acres (0.32 km2) were purchased by John T. Ball, a merchant from Kemper County. Ragsdale and Ball, credited as the city's pioneers, proceeded to divide their respective land portions to create parcels for new urban development.

There was a fierce rivalry concerning the suggested name for the town. The residents were divided, with Ball and the more industrial members supporting the name "Meridian," associating it with "junction." On the other hand, the agrarian group favored "<unk>," derived from a local creek's name meaning "mad river" in a Native American language. Ragsdale suggested "Ragsdale City." To resolve the dispute, Ball installed a station house on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad with a sign that alternated daily between "Meridian" and "<unk>." Eventually, the increasing number of railroad workers influenced the decision, leading to the permanent placement of "Meridian" on the station sign. The town was formally established as Meridian on February 10, 1860, following its incorporation.

Meridian, a small village at the beginning of the American Civil War in 1861, held a crucial position at a railroad junction, prompting the Confederates to erect multiple military facilities to aid in the war efforts. In 1864, during the Battle of Meridian, General William Tecumseh Sherman led his troops into the town, demolishing the railways in all directions, as well as an arsenal and vast storage facilities; a significant portion of the structures were set ablaze by his troops. Sherman was quoted as stating post-event, "Meridian, along with its depots, warehouses, arsenal, hospitals, offices, hotels, and barracks, no longer survives." Despite the devastation, the city's rail lines were swiftly restored and operational within 26 days of the battle. Racial tensions persisted throughout the Reconstruction period, culminating in the 1871 riot subsequent to a fire that inflicted damage on numerous businesses.

Following the Civil War, the town thrived and reached its peak known as the "Golden Age" between 1880 and 1910. The introduction of railroads in the region not only facilitated transportation but also attracted various industries, leading to a surge in the population. With the growing number of residents, commercial activities flourished in the downtown area. From 1890 to 1930, Meridian held the distinction of being the largest city in Mississippi and emerged as a prominent manufacturing hub in the Southern region. Numerous iconic landmarks in the city, such as the Grand Opera House constructed in 1890, the Wechsler School in 1894, two Carnegie libraries in 1913, and the <unk> Building, which became Meridian's tallest skyscraper in 1929, were built during or shortly after this prosperous period.

The city's expansion was fueled by the proactive measures of the commission government, which facilitated the establishment of 90 new industrial plants in 1913 and the flourishing automobile sector in the 1920s. Despite the economic downturn triggered by the stock market crash of 1929 and the subsequent Great Depression, the city remained attractive to prospective businesses. In line with the era's trend of seeking solace from harsh realities, downtown Meridian saw the introduction of the S. H. Kress & Co. building, designed to offer luxury to the general public, alongside the Temple Theater, repurposed as a cinema. Additionally, the federal courthouse was erected in 1933 through a WPA initiative.

Following a slight economic downturn towards the end of the Depression, the nation was thrust into World War II, reigniting the significance of railroads. Railways played a crucial role in ferrying gasoline and recyclable materials for constructing military equipment, leading to Meridian re-emerging as the primary rail hub in the region. This economic revival persisted until the 1950s when private automobiles and the Interstate Highway System overshadowed passenger rail travel. The subsequent decline of the railway sector led to notable job cuts and triggered an outmigration of workers to different regions.

During the 1960s American Civil Rights Movement, Meridian housed a Council of Federated Organizations (COFO) office and various activist groups. Local activist James Chaney, Michael Schwerner, Rita Schwerner, Andrew Goodman, and other volunteers aimed to establish a community center to provide classes for African Americans in the region to empower them to vote. The local white population opposed the activism, leading to frequent violent racial conflicts. In June 1964, Chaney, Schwerner, and Goodman traveled to Neshoba County, Mississippi, to meet with members of a black church that had suffered a bombing and arson attack. The trio disappeared on their way back to Meridian that night, and after an extensive FBI probe, their deceased bodies were discovered buried in a dam two months later.

Seven members of the Ku Klux Klan, one of whom was a deputy sheriff, were found guilty of violating the civil rights of the victims in the federal courthouse in Meridian. In a significant moment, a white jury convicted a white official for his involvement in a civil rights-related murder. Following the trial, three individuals were acquitted. Years later, in 2005, the state reopened the case and for the first time pressed charges. Edgar Ray Killen was found guilty of manslaughter and received a 60-year prison sentence. Meridian paid tribute to one of the victims, Chaney, by renaming a section of 49th Avenue in his honor and establishing an annual memorial service.

In the 1960s, with the introduction of highways facilitating commuting, a shift occurred where residents started relocating from downtown to new housing subdivisions in the north. As strip commercial activities moved into downtown, the city took action in the 1970s and 80s by establishing historic districts to safeguard the city's architectural heritage. The Meridian Historic Districts and Landmarks Commission was established in 1979, followed by the inception of the Meridian Main Street program in 1985.

Meridian Main Street undertook various initiatives to rejuvenate the downtown area, such as the establishment of a new Amtrak Station in 1997 that mirrored the design of the demolished historic train station from Meridian's Golden Age. Additional endeavors encompassed the refurbishment of the Rosenbaum Building in 2001 and Weidmann's Restaurant in 2002, alongside advocacy for cohesive urban design. In collaboration with The Riley Foundation, Meridian Main Street facilitated the restoration and transformation of the esteemed Grand Opera House in 2006 into the "Mississippi State University Riley Center for Education and the Performing Arts."

After the transfer of ownership of Meridian Main Street to the Alliance for Downtown Meridian in late 2007, the two organizations, in collaboration with the Meridian Downtown Association, took the lead in the downtown revitalization project. The Alliance acts as an overarching body, enabling the other groups to utilize its support team and facilities, and concurrently acts as a mediator between them. Initially, there were plans in progress to refurbish the <unk> Building; however, these plans were terminated by the newly elected Mayor Cheri Barry in early 2010. Presently, the Alliance plays a crucial role in fostering further growth and preservation downtown, with a focus on supporting businesses like specialty stores, eateries, and bars to enhance downtown's vibrancy both during the day and night. The Meridian Downtown Association concentrates on enhancing pedestrian activity downtown through the organization of special events, while the Meridian Main Street program is dedicated to bolstering the existing businesses downtown.

Meridian's role as a crucial railroad junction has led to the establishment of numerous hotels to accommodate travelers. Prior to Meridian's prosperous era, notable hotels such as the Great Southern and Grand Avenue hotels were already in place by the late 19th century. The expansion of railroads and the opening of the original Union Station in 1906 further fueled the development of hotels to cater to the increasing number of passengers and workers. The Elmira Hotel was erected in 1905, followed by the construction of the Terminal Hotel in 1910. Hotel Meridian and Union Hotel were also added to the city's hospitality offerings in 1907 and 1908, respectively. Union Hotel gained recognition by being listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979, while Hotel Meridian and Grand Avenue Hotel were designated as contributing properties within the Meridian Urban Center Historic District.

With the city's expansion, the hotels mirrored the aspirations driven by the flourishing economy, exemplified by the construction of the Lamar Hotel, an eleven-story skyscraper erected in 1927. This historical hotel was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1979 and later repurposed as a county annex building. Recognized as a Mississippi Landmark in 1988, the Lamar Hotel stands as a testament to the city's growth and evolution.

Constructed in 1931, the E.F. Young Hotel stood as a prominent establishment in the African American business sector that emerged towards the western part of the city. It served as a rare accommodation option for African American travelers during the era of segregation, offering a place to stay when few others were available.

During the 1960s and '70s, with the growth of city suburbs, many hotels relocated from downtown. Following the revitalization of the Riley Center in 2006, there has been a surge in the need for a new hotel in the downtown area. Plans for repurposing the <unk> Building for this venture were put forth; however, progress halted due to a shift in city leadership. In response, the <unk> Preservation Society was established in 2013 to promote community engagement and financial backing for the restoration of the building, offering tours of the ground floor and organizing commemorative events.

Meridian boasts nine historical districts that have been officially recognized and listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Meridian Downtown Historic District is an amalgamation of the Meridian Urban Center Historic District and the Union Station Historic District. These districts showcase a variety of architectural styles predominantly dating back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries, such as Queen Anne, Colonial Revival, Italianate, Art Deco, Late Victorian, and Bungalow.

The governance structure in Meridian has been the mayor-council or "strong mayor" model since 1985. Every four years, the population elects a mayor, while the city council's five members are elected from each of the city's five wards, which are seen as individual districts. The mayor, as the primary executive officer, oversees the daily operations of the city government. On the other hand, the city council acts as the legislative body, establishing policies and approving the city's annual operating budget.

City Hall, situated at 601 23rd Avenue and recognized on the National Register of Historic Places, is overseen by Mayor Percy Bland. The city council comprises Dr. George M. Thomas, representing Ward 1, Kenneth Dustin Markham from Ward 2, Barbara Henson from Ward 3, Kim Houston from Ward 4, and Randy Hammon from Ward 5. Pam McInnis serves as the council clerk, and the city has a workforce totaling 570 employees.

Following Hurricane Katrina in 2005, the city formed its own Department of Homeland Security (DHS), making it the sole local DHS in the state. Covering a region spanning nine counties, the department received $2.5 million in grants from various entities, including the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency. Subsequently, they initiated training programs for law enforcement officers from neighboring Southern states in passenger rail rescue operations. Additionally, the department started offering courses to the public on topics such as basic handgun usage, Boy Scout first aid, hunting, and firearms handling. In times of crises like Hurricane Ivan in September 2005, the DHS played a key role in setting up and supporting shelters for up to 700 evacuees. Presently, the city leads one of the task forces within the Mississippi DHS, which comprises three teams covering nine counties each.

Under the leadership of police chief Lee <unk>, the Meridian Police Department, established in 2009, comprises a total of 115 full-time officers, supplemented by part-time and reserve personnel. In the same year, the department's Criminal Investigations Division handled 4000 cases, with 2000 classified as felonies. Crime rates in 2000 saw a slight increase compared to the previous year, with Meridian being recognized as the safest city in Mississippi for its population exceeding 30,000. The East Mississippi Correctional Facility, managed by the GEO Group on behalf of the Mississippi Department of Corrections, is situated in unincorporated Lauderdale County near Meridian. Overseeing the Meridian Fire Department is Anthony Clayton, who oversaw the response to more than 1600 calls in 2009, comprising 123 structural fires and 609 emergency service requests.

In Mississippi state politics, the city is divided into three sections on the Senate district map. Historically, prior to the transition to the Republican Party, white voters in the region supported Democratic candidates. This trend dates back to the late 1800s when Mississippi predominantly aligned with the Democratic Party as a single-party state.

The city's expansion has mirrored the interplay of various social and economic influences. The population consistently grew in each census following the city's establishment until 1970, with growth rates fluctuating between 165% and as low as 0.2%. However, in the 1970 census, there was a decrease in population, followed by a slight increase by 1980. Subsequently, there was a gradual decline in population, which started to rise again since the early 2000s. Between 1980 and 2000, there was a decline of over 14% in the population. By the 2000 census, the city had a population of 39,968, with a population density of 885.9 inhabitants per square mile (342.0/km2). By 2008, the city ranked as the sixth largest in the state. The population saw an increase by 2010.

Meridian is the main city in the Meridian metropolitan area, comprising three counties – Clarke, Kemper, and Lauderdale – with a total population of 106,139 as of 2009. The city has a population of 232,900 within a 45-mile (72 km) radius and 526,500 within a 65-mile (105 km) radius.

While the city's overall population growth has shown fluctuations over time, there has been a consistent increase in both the number and proportion of residents who are not white. The sole decrease in this demographic occurred between 1960 and 1970, coinciding with a notable decline in the city's total population. According to the 2010 Census data, the city's racial composition was comprised of 61.55% African American, 35.71% White, 0.9% Asian, 0.2% Native American, less than 0.02% Pacific Islander, 0.59% from other races, and 0.89% from two or more races. Additionally, individuals of Hispanic or Latino descent, regardless of race, accounted for 1.75% of the total population.

As per the 2000 Census data, out of the 17,890 housing units within the city limits, 15,966 were occupied, with 10,033 occupied by families. Among the occupied households, 31.1% had children under 18, 36.2% were married couples, 23.3% were female householders without a husband present, and 37.2% were non-family households. Additionally, 33.2% of all households consisted of individuals, and 14.0% had a person aged 65 or older living alone. The average household size was 2.39, and the average family size was 3.06. Since 1970, the average household size has gradually decreased from 3.04. The median age of Meridian has also risen from 30.4 in 1970 to 34.6 in 2000.

In the city, the median household income was $25,085, while the median family income was $31,062. Male individuals had a median income of $29,404 compared to $19,702 for females. The per capita income in the city stood at $15,255. Approximately 24.6% of families and 28.6% of the population lived below the poverty line, including 40.8% of individuals under 18 and 22.0% of those aged 65 or older.

The population in and around Meridian is quite religious, with 65.2% of Lauderdale County residents being part of a religious group, which is higher than the national average of 50.2%. In 2000, of those affiliated, 59.0% were Southern Baptist Convention members, 18.6% were part of the United Methodist Church, and 3.7% were affiliated with the Catholic Church.

Immigrant Jews from Germany and eastern Europe played a significant role in the city's economic growth by establishing businesses and services. The establishment of Congregation Beth Israel in 1868 coincided with the city's prosperous "Golden Age." At its peak in 1927, Meridian boasted the largest Jewish community in the state, with 575 Jewish residents. However, the Jewish population in Meridian has dwindled over the years, and today only around 40 Jewish individuals, primarily seniors, reside in the city.

Meridian, situated in Lauderdale County, Mississippi, lies in the North Central Hills region. As per data from the United States Census Bureau, the city spans 45.9 square miles (119 km2), encompassing 45.1 square miles (117 km2) of land and 0.8 square miles (2.1 km2) of water. Positioned with respect to major highways, Meridian is 93 miles (150 km) east of Jackson, Mississippi; 154 miles (248 km) west of Birmingham, Alabama; 202 miles (325 km) northeast of New Orleans, Louisiana; 231 miles (372 km) southeast of Memphis, Tennessee; and 297 miles (478 km) west of Atlanta, Georgia. The vicinity of the city is characterized by cotton and corn fields, oak and pine forests, and a terrain comprising clay hills and the low-lying areas of the headwaters of the <unk> River.

The natural landscape in the urban center of the city has been altered through grading, while retaining its gently undulating terrain in the surrounding areas. The city features numerous small creeks, with small lakes and wooded areas situated in the north and south. For instance, <unk> Creek flows through the southern part of the city, dividing into Gallagher's Creek that meanders through the city center. Loper's Creek courses through the far-western region, and smaller waterways like Shearer's Branch, Magnolia Creek, and Robbins Creek are scattered across the city.

Meridian falls within the humid subtropical climate zone, with summer temperatures ranging from an average high of about 90 °F (32 °C) to a low of around 70 °F (21 °C) from June to August. In winter, temperatures typically range from an average maximum of approximately 60 °F (16 °C) to a minimum of 35 °F (2 °C) between December and February. July stands as the warmest month, with an average high of 92.9 °F (33.8 °C), while January marks the coldest month of the year, with an average low of 34.7 °F (1.5 °C).

The city receives an average annual precipitation of 58.65 inches (1,490 mm), with rainfall spread relatively evenly throughout the year. March stands out as the wettest month, with an average of 6.93 inches (176 mm) of rainfall. Thunderstorms are a common source of precipitation, occurring frequently during the summer months but also throughout the year. Some of these thunderstorms can be severe, with the potential for damaging winds, large hail, lightning, and heavy rain. The highest occurrence of severe thunderstorms is typically in the spring, with a secondary peak in the fall, carrying the additional risk of tornadoes.

In the early stages, the economy heavily relied on the railroads in the vicinity. By the turn of the 20th century, the city stood as the largest in Mississippi, boasting five major rail lines and facilitating the daily passage of 44 trains. Not only did the city's economy hinge on the functioning of these rail networks, but it also thrived on the transportation of commodities like timber and cotton. Leveraging these rail-centric sectors, the city wielded significant economic influence in both the state and the region from approximately 1890 to 1930. Despite facing a slowdown due to the waning fortunes of the railroad industry in the 1950s, the city underwent a transformation, transitioning from a predominantly railroad-oriented economy to a more diversified one. Presently, sectors such as healthcare, military, and manufacturing have emerged as the primary employers in the region.

Meridian, in conjunction with Lauderdale County and the city of Marion, is supported by the East Mississippi Business Development Corporation, established in 1996 by local business leaders. As of April 2010, Meridian had a civilian labor force of 15,420 individuals. The city plays a central role as a employment, retail, health care, and cultural hub, serving a population of 232,900 within a 45-mile radius and 526,500 within a 65-mile radius, with 104,600 and 234,200 individuals in the labor force, respectively. Notably, 80% of Lauderdale County's workforce and 90% of residents living within 45 miles are employed within the county.

In Lauderdale County, as of April 2010, the healthcare sector employed 6,260 individuals. Among the key healthcare organizations in the area, Rush Hospital stands out as the largest employer with a workforce of 2,610, followed by East Mississippi State Hospital with 1,500 employees and Anderson Hospital with 1,475. Meridian hosts three hospitals and various other healthcare facilities, including Jeff Anderson Regional Medical Center known for its cardiovascular surgery, Level II newborn intensive care unit, and health and fitness center. Rush Foundation Hospital and Rush Health Systems manage a Specialty Hospital of Meridian that caters to long-term care needs of patients requiring extended recovery time in a hospital setting. Riley Hospital offers specialized centers for stroke treatment and rehabilitation services. Additional healthcare establishments in Meridian encompass the Alliance Health Center and East Mississippi State Hospital, the latter being operational since 1882.

Retail is a significant source of employment in the county, with 5,280 individuals working in this sector as of April 2010. The city sees an annual expenditure of nearly $2 billion on retail goods. The Bonita Lakes Mall, spanning 633,685 square feet (58,871 m2), hosts a variety of shopping options, such as department stores, specialty shops, restaurants, eateries, and United Artists Theatres. The first phase of Meridian Crossroads, a 375,000 square foot (34,800 m2) shopping center in the Bonita Lakes vicinity, was finished in November 2007, greatly enhancing the retail landscape. Moreover, the retail area on North Hills Street has seen continuous growth, with additional retail and office space opening near the Highway 19 Walmart Supercenter in March 2007.

The region is supported by two military installations, Naval Air Station Meridian and Key Field, which offer employment opportunities to over 4,000 local residents. Naval Air Station Meridian specializes in training naval carrier pilots and other military personnel, and hosts the Regional Counter-Drug Training Academy (RCTA) for law enforcement narcotics training in the southeastern United States. The city houses the state's inaugural Department of Homeland Security, leading a regional response team spanning nine counties and a task force covering twenty-nine counties. Key Field gained renown in 1935 when brothers Fred and Al Key set a world endurance flight record there. Today, Key Field is home to the 186th Air Refueling Wing of the Air National Guard and supports the 185th Aviation Brigade of the Army National Guard. The base features an aviation history exhibit and is the location of Meridian's Aviation Museum.

In April 2010, Lauderdale County had a total manufacturing workforce of 2,850 individuals. One of the prominent companies in the region is Peavey Electronics Corporation, known for producing guitars, amplifiers, and sound equipment for over five decades. Additionally, the area accommodates various other enterprises such as Avery Dennison, Structural Steel Services, Sara Lee, Tower Automotive, and [Company Name]. Notably, the city hosts four industrial parks to support its industrial activities.

The MSU Riley Center in downtown Meridian is a significant source of income through tourism, arts, and entertainment transactions, drawing over 60,000 visitors annually for various events. Loeb's Department Store, a longstanding Mississippi fashion icon located on Front St, has upheld its heritage over four generations of family management, specializing in high-quality men's and women's attire since its establishment in 1887 by Alex Loeb.

Meridian, renowned for its rich artistic heritage spanning over a century, boasts a plethora of art and cultural institutions along with hosting numerous cultural gatherings. The Meridian Art League, among the city's pioneering art groups, was founded in February 1933. Initially, art displays were showcased at the Lamar Hotel in downtown Meridian. However, following a rebranding to the Meridian Art Association in 1949, exhibitions were dispersed across various venues in the city. Upon the closure of the Carnegie library at 25th Ave and 7th St, the Art Association transformed the edifice into the Meridian Museum of Art, offering a permanent exhibition space. Inaugurated in 1970, the museum has continuously presented rotating exhibitions and a myriad of educational programs catering to both students and adults. The museum curates over thirty exhibitions annually, encompassing a wide array of art forms from traditional decorative arts to ethnographic pieces, tribal artifacts, photography, crafts, and diverse artistic creations. The collection also comprises portraits from the 18th and 19th centuries, 20th-century photography, and several sculptures.

Established in 1978, the Meridian Council for the Arts (MCA) serves as the official arts agency for Meridian and Lauderdale County. Every year, MCA administers its Community Art Grants program, organizes the annual <unk> Festival, hosts various workshops, and coordinates special events. The organization collaborates with numerous local arts groups, such as the Meridian Museum of Art, the historic Meridian Little Theatre, and the acclaimed Meridian Symphony Orchestra. The Meridian Little Theatre, established in 1932, is one of the oldest subscription-based community theaters in the South, attracting over 22,000 attendees each season, solidifying its status as Mississippi's most popular community theater. Since its inception in 1961, the Meridian Symphony Orchestra (MSO) has actively contributed to the local arts scene, holding its inaugural concert in 1962 and embarking on its first full season in 1963. Notably, in 1965, the MSO featured its first international soloist, Elena <unk>, marking a significant milestone. Over the years, the orchestra has played a pivotal role in fostering music education by assisting the Meridian Public School District in establishing orchestra and strings programs, as well as forming the Meridian Symphony Chorus. Dr. Claire Fox Hillard has been the esteemed conductor of the orchestra since 1991. In February 2011, the MSO commemorated its 50th anniversary with a remarkable performance by renowned violinist Itzhak Perlman.

The Grand Opera House of the city, constructed in 1889 by half siblings Israel Marks and Levi Rothenberg, showcased numerous renowned artists and productions throughout its active years. Its inaugural show was a performance of Johann Strauss II's "The Gypsy Baron" by a German troupe. Following closure during the late 1920s amid the Great Depression, the opera house remained deserted for about seven decades. The revival of the building commenced in 2000 following a $10 million endowment from the Riley Foundation, established locally in 1998, supplemented by $15 million from various city, county, and federal subsidies. Reopened in September 2006 as the "Mississippi State University Riley Center for Education and Performing Arts," the refurbished venue comprises a 950-seat auditorium for live shows, a 200-seat studio theater, and 30,000 square feet (2,787 m2) of event space. The Riley Center has become a focal point, drawing over 60,000 visitors annually to downtown Meridian for conferences, gatherings, and performances.

Meridian is widely recognized as a valuable architectural gem, being one of the most well-preserved cities in the country from the early 1900s. It attracts architecture students from across the United States and Canada who visit in groups as part of their studies, drawn by the city's many buildings designed by renowned architects. Among these, the only residence in the southern United States designed by the noted Canadian architect Louis S. Curtiss can be found on Highland Park. The <unk> Building, designed by Frank Fort, is celebrated as one of the finest Art Deco skyscrapers in the country and is often likened to Detroit's iconic Fisher Building. Wallace Neff, a prominent architect from California, created several homes in Meridian and the neighboring Alabama Black Belt, influenced by his family connections to the railroad industry executives in Meridian and Selma. Much of Neff's work is concentrated in the early blocks of Poplar Springs Drive, where his design echoes the style of Falcon Lair, Rudolph Valentino's residence in Benedict Canyon, Beverly Hills. Unfortunately, one of Neff's creations was lost during the expansion of Anderson Hospital in 1990, and another in Marion Park succumbed to a fire in the 1950s. The Meridian Post Office stands out for its interior adorned with bronze and Verde marble, showcasing the grandeur typical of post office buildings constructed in prosperous cities during the 1920s. Originally featuring <unk> lighting, these fixtures were regrettably removed during a renovation in the 1960s and are now housed in private residences on Poplar Springs Drive and in North Hills.

Meridian has been designated as the forthcoming site for the Mississippi Arts and Entertainment Center. The Mississippi Legislature endorsed the proposal in 2001, with a commitment in 2006 to allocate $4 million if private donors could match $8 million. In September 2007, the city contributed $50,000 towards the initiative. The envisioned center, spanning 175 acres at Bonita Lakes, is set to feature an open-air amphitheater, an indoor music venue, and a Hall of Fame celebrating Mississippian artists. The Hall of Fame is slated to be housed in the former Montana's building downtown, which was purchased alongside the neighboring Meridian Hotel property for $300,000 in July 2010. In February 2009, the Center unveiled its Walk of Fame outside the Riley Center to generate interest in the future Hall of Fame. "Angel of Death" is the first song on Slayer's 1986 album Reign in Blood, composed by the band's guitarist Jeff Hanneman. The lyrics and music draw inspiration from the actions of Josef Mengele, a Nazi doctor notorious for his human experiments at Auschwitz during World War II. The song triggered allegations of Nazi sympathies and racism against Slayer over the years.

Despite the debate surrounding the track and its connection to the postponement of Reign in Blood's release, "Angel of Death" is included in all of Slayer's live albums and DVDs and has been featured in various films. Critics praised the song, with Steve Huey from AllMusic labeling it a "classic."

During a tour with the band, Slayer's guitarist Jeff Hanneman composed the song "Angel of Death" after immersing himself in books about Nazi doctor Josef Mengele. Hanneman recalled purchasing two books on Mengele during a stop, finding the subject matter deeply disturbing. He explained that when it was time to work on the record, the vivid details from the books inspired the lyrics for "Angel of Death."

The song's lyrics describe Mengele's medical procedures on inmates at the Auschwitz camp in World War II, focusing on groups like dwarfs and twins. These experiments, mentioned in "Angel of Death," encompassed a range of physical and mental assessments. They involved surgeries without pain relief, blood transfusions among twins, endurance trials, gas chambers, injections of deadly pathogens, gender reassignment surgeries, organ and limb removals, and other brutal practices.

The line " <unk> together, joining heads. Just a matter of time 'til you rip yourselves apart," found in the penultimate verse, alludes to the accusation that Mengele surgically connected twins, one of whom was deformed. According to Auschwitz survivor Vera Alexander's testimony during the 1961 trial of SS officer Adolf Eichmann, it was claimed that Mengele sewed the hunchbacked child to the other twin, binding their wrists together as well. This assertion gained prominence after Alexander appeared in the 1985 documentary The Search for Mengele, referenced by various writers, including Mengele expert Gerald Posner.

The lyrical themes and artwork of "Angel of Death" caused a postponement in the release of Slayer's 1986 album Reign in Blood. The band was under Def Jam Records, but its distributor, Columbia Records, declined to release the album because they found the content too graphic. Eventually, Geffen Records distributed Reign in Blood on October 7, 1986, although the controversy surrounding it led to the album not being included in Geffen Records' official release schedule.
